alert.note: Alert for Allegan; Barry; Calhoun; Clinton; Eaton; Gratiot; Ingham; Ionia; Jackson; Kalamazoo; Kent; Montcalm; Ottawa; Van Buren (Michigan) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued February 16 at 12:05PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids
info.description: ...Minor flooding and Ice Jams possible through this weekend... Rain and rapidly melting snow will bring river levels up significantly in the Grand and Kalamazoo River basins over the next several days. A few locations could see water levels near or slightly above bankfull. These conditions are also favorable for ice jam formation, especially along the Grand River. Snow has begun to melt quickly, especially along and south of I-96. Rain will move in late this afternoon, and add around three-quarters of an inch of water to the ongoing snowmelt. Frozen ground will prevent much of this water from being able to soak in, and instead send even more water into the river systems. There will likely be a lot of standing water in low spots and poor drainage areas. The smaller creeks and streams will rise first, followed by the middle sized rivers (Portage, Sycamore Creek, Red Cedar, and Looking Glass) on Thursday and Friday. As we move into the weekend, the mainstem Grand and Kalamazoo rivers will see more substantial rises. No widespread flooding is expected, but several of the tributary rivers around the Lansing area will probably rise up to near-flood stage levels over the next few days. The bigger concern is that the rising water levels may also be enough to start breaking up some of the river ice we currently have. Ice is most widespread along the Grand River and its tributaries, so this is where the risk of an ice jam forming are the highest, especially as we head through the weekend. Ice jams are notoriously unpredictable, and can lead to water rises much faster than are typically experienced on our rivers. Anyone living or working along the rivers in West Michigan should pay extra attention over the next week to river conditions, and have a plan to respond if water levels start to rise quickly. This statement will be updated as necessary. The latest information is always available at www.weather.gov/GrandRapids
